official-title.#text:
Honoring the life of Jeanne Sobelson Manford for her fierce advocacy on behalf of the lesbian, gay,
			 bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community as they and their allies
			 celebrate Pride month during the month of June, reflect on the progress
			 made towards equality, and remember activists like Jeanne who spent their
			 lives fighting for their rights.

cosponsor.#text: Mr. Sean Patrick Maloney of New York

cosponsor.#tail: ) submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: That the
honors the life and work of Jeanne Sobelson Manford;

recognizes Jeanne Sobelson Manford as a national hero who advanced the rights of lesbian, gay,
			 bisexual and transgender (LGBT) people in the United States; and

commends Jeanne Sobelson Manford for helping to realize the founders’ goal of creating a more
			 perfect union based on the ideal that all men and women are created equal.

Whereas Jeanne Sobelson Manford was born in Queens, New York, on December 4, 1920, to Charles and
			 Sadie Sobelson;

Whereas she earned her bachelor’s degree from the City University of New York’s Queens College and
			 became an elementary school teacher at P.S. 32;
Whereas she married her husband Jules Manford and had three children Charles, Morty, and Suzanne;
Whereas in April 1972, her openly gay son Morty was beaten during a gay rights protest;

Whereas in the aftermath of her son’s beating Jeanne, together with her husband Jules, became a
			 staunch advocate of LGBT rights;

quote.#text: Parents of Gays Unite in Support for our Children

text.#text:
Whereas while marching in one of New York City’s first Pride parades, known as the Christopher
			 Street Liberation Day Parade, on June 25, 1972, with her son, Jeanne
			 carried a now-famous sign reading,

Whereas this important show of support was the impetus for her founding the organization Parents,
			 Friends and Family of Lesbians and Gays, now known as PFLAG;

Whereas PFLAG, through its core values of meeting people where they are and collaborating with
			 others, seeks to relay its vision through support for families, allies,
			 and people who are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and
			 queer/questioning (LGBTQ), education about the unique issues and
			 challenges that people who are LGBTQ face, and advocacy in communities to
			 change attitudes and create policies and laws that achieve full equality
			 for people who are LGBTQ;

Whereas Jeanne Manford became an advocate for people with AIDS because of the death of her son and
			 so many others whose lives were far too short;

Whereas Jeanne Manford was honored as the Grand Marshal of the first Queens Pride Parade, held in
			 June 1993;

, courts have continuously overturned State bans on same-sex
			 marriage, leading to equal marriage rights for people in 19 States and the
			 District of Columbia and legal challenges to same-sex marriage bans
			 pending in 30 other States;

text.#text: Whereas since the landmark decision of United States v. Windsor invalidating the

Whereas this extraordinary show of support represents a rapid change in attitudes sparked by the
			 important work of advocates like Jeanne Sobelson Manford;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
posthumously awarded Jeanne the Presidential Citizens Medal on
			 February 15, 2013, he remarked that Jeanne,

text.#text: Whereas when

quote.#text:
Took to the streets with a simple message: No matter who her son was—no matter who he loved—she
			 loved him, and wouldn’t put up with this kind of nonsense. And in that
			 simple act, she inspired a movement and gave rise to a national
			 organization that has given so much support to parents and families and
			 friends, and helped to change this country.

text.#text:
Whereas Jeanne demonstrated to us in her life and inspires us today through her legacy that one
			 voice can change the world;
Whereas Jeanne’s courage lives on in PFLAG’s work and in the progress for which she fought; and

Whereas Jeanne Manford insisted that equality knows no bounds, including that of sexual orientation
			 or gender identity: Now, therefore, be it
